dashed.$description: borderStyle.dashed — Dashed border style. Use for: drop zones, placeholder elements, 'add new' areas, temporary states, grouping without containment. Suggests incompleteness or potential. Common in: drag-and-drop zones, placeholder cards, dashed separators.

dotted.$description: borderStyle.dotted — Dotted border style. Use for: decorative elements, subtle separators, accessibility focus alternatives, lightweight boundaries. Softer than dashed. Common in: decorative dividers, coupon borders, alternative focus styles.

none.$description: borderStyle.none — No border style. Use for: removing inherited borders, clean/minimal designs, when using other separation methods. CSS keyword. Equivalent to border-style: none;.

solid.$description: borderStyle.solid — Solid border style. DEFAULT for all standard borders. Use for: inputs, cards, buttons, tables, containers. Continuous line - clean and professional. CSS keyword.

medium.$description: borderWidth.medium — Medium border (2px). Use for: emphasis, active/selected states, focus indicators, section dividers. More prominent than thin - draws attention. Common in: active tab indicators, selected items, heavy dividers, emphasized cards.

none.$description: borderWidth.none — No border (0px). Use for: removing inherited borders, borderless variants, flat designs. CSS: border-width: 0; Common in: ghost buttons, flat cards, seamless containers.

thick.$description: borderWidth.thick — Thick border (4px). Use for: strong emphasis, decorative elements, major section dividers, brand accents. Very prominent - use sparingly. Common in: hero sections, brand elements, major visual accents, side indicators.

thin.$description: borderWidth.thin — Thin border (1px). DEFAULT for most UI borders. Use for: input fields, cards, tables, subtle containment, dividers. Provides structure without visual weight. Common in: Input, Select, Card, Table, dividers, most bordered elements.

footer.$description: boxShadow.footer — Footer shadow - upward-casting shadow for fixed footers. Use for: sticky footers, bottom navigation bars, action bars at bottom of screen. Shadow casts upward to show footer is above scrolling content. Common in: sticky page footers, bottom action bars, mobile bottom nav.

inset.$description: boxShadow.inset — Inset shadow - pressed/recessed appearance. Use for: pressed button states, input:focus, toggle switches (off state), embedded content areas. Creates illusion of pressing INTO the surface. Common in: Button:active, pressed toggles, embedded wells, search input backgrounds.

lg.$description: boxShadow.lg — Large shadow - high elevation (16-24dp). Use for: dialogs, modals, drawers, notification toasts, temporary UI surfaces. Significantly elevated - demands attention. Common in: Modal dialogs, side Drawer, Toast notifications, contextual menus requiring focus.

md.$description: boxShadow.md — Medium shadow - moderate elevation (8-12dp). DEFAULT for floating elements. Use for: dropdown menus, popovers, tooltips, floating action buttons, autocomplete lists. Clearly floating above content. Common in: Dropdown menu, Popover, Select options, Autocomplete, FAB.

none.$description: boxShadow.none — No shadow - flat appearance. Use for: flat design elements, removing inherited shadows, elements that should appear flush with background, focus states that use outline instead. CSS keyword. Common in: flat buttons, inline elements, focus states using outline.

sm.$description: boxShadow.sm — Small shadow - low elevation (4-6dp). Use for: card hover states, raised buttons, navigation elements, slightly prominent containers. Noticeable but not dramatic elevation. Common in: Card:hover, Button:raised, Dropdown trigger, Navigation bar, elevated sections.

xl.$description: boxShadow.xl — Extra large shadow - maximum elevation (24dp+). Use for: critical modals, full-screen overlays, maximum prominence elements. Dramatic elevation - use sparingly. Common in: Full-screen modals, critical dialogs, onboarding overlays, image lightboxes.

xs.$description: boxShadow.xs — Extra small shadow - minimal elevation (1-2dp). Use for: subtle depth on cards at rest, input fields, low-emphasis containers, elements that could be flat. Barely noticeable - adds dimension without prominence. Common in: Card default state, Input fields, Table rows, subtle separation.

lg.$description: breakpoints.lg — Large breakpoint (1200px). Use for: large laptops, standard desktop monitors. Generous space available. Typical changes: four-column grids, expanded dashboards, side panels. Content max-widths often kick in here to prevent over-stretching.

md.$description: breakpoints.md — Medium breakpoint (992px). Use for: tablets in landscape, standard laptops, small desktops. Full desktop layouts are comfortable. Typical changes: three-column layouts, full navigation, expanded sidebars. Most 'desktop' designs target this minimum.

sm.$description: breakpoints.sm — Small breakpoint (768px). Use for: tablets in portrait, small laptops. Two-column layouts become comfortable. Typical changes: sidebars can appear, cards go 2-up, navigation expands. Common tablet breakpoint. Desktop-like experiences begin here.

xl.$description: breakpoints.xl — Extra large breakpoint (1408px). Use for: large desktop monitors, high-resolution displays. Maximum layouts. Typical changes: ultra-wide layouts, multi-panel views, data-dense dashboards. Consider max-width constraints - too wide hurts readability.

xs.$description: breakpoints.xs — Extra small breakpoint (576px). Use for: large phones in landscape, small tablets. Content starts having room to breathe. Typical changes: side-by-side layouts begin, hiding mobile-only elements. Above this: no longer 'mobile-only' context.

black.$description: color.base.black — Pure black. Use for: dark theme text emphasis, high-contrast borders. Contrast ratio with white: 21:1 (WCAG AAA). Rarely used directly - prefer dark.9 for softer blacks or semantic color.text token.

0.$description: color.base.blue.0 — Lightest blue - primary light backgrounds, selected row highlights

1.$description: color.base.blue.1 — Light blue - hover backgrounds, info alert backgrounds

2.$description: color.base.blue.2 — Mid-light blue - progress bars, decorative

3.$description: color.base.blue.3 — Medium blue - icons on light backgrounds

4.$description: color.base.blue.4 — Mid blue - primary buttons on dark theme, links on dark

5.$description: color.base.blue.5 — Base blue - primary buttons, links (light theme)

6.$description: color.base.blue.6 — Dark blue - primary brand color, main CTAs, navigation active states

7.$description: color.base.blue.7 — Darker blue - pressed states, text on light blue backgrounds

8.$description: color.base.blue.8 — Very dark blue - high contrast text

9.$description: color.base.blue.9 — Darkest blue - maximum emphasis, dark accents

9.$description: color.base.dark.9 — Darkest - near-black for maximum contrast elements

1.$description: color.base.gray.1 — Light gray - input backgrounds, disabled backgrounds, table headers

2.$description: color.base.gray.2 — Mid-light gray - borders, dividers, inactive tabs

6.$description: color.base.gray.6 — Dark gray - secondary text (7:1 on white = AAA), labels

8.$description: color.base.gray.8 — Very dark gray - high-emphasis text on light backgrounds

9.$description: color.base.gray.9 — Darkest gray - headings, maximum emphasis text

3.$description: color.base.green.3 — Medium green - success icons on light backgrounds

6.$description: color.base.green.6 — Dark green - success text on white (5:1 contrast = AA)

7.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.steel.7 — Steel — balanced mid-tone neutral — tint step 7.

8.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.steel.8 — Steel — balanced mid-tone neutral — tint step 8.

9.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.steel.9 — Steel — balanced mid-tone neutral — tint step 9.

0.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.verdigris.0 — Verdigris — nature-inspired supporting color — tint step 0.

1.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.verdigris.1 — Verdigris — nature-inspired supporting color — tint step 1.

2.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.verdigris.2 — Verdigris — nature-inspired supporting color — tint step 2.

3.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.verdigris.3 — Verdigris — nature-inspired supporting color — base color (step 3, pinned to official brand hex).

4.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.verdigris.4 — Verdigris — nature-inspired supporting color — tint step 4.

5.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.verdigris.5 — Verdigris — nature-inspired supporting color — tint step 5.

6.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.verdigris.6 — Verdigris — nature-inspired supporting color — tint step 6.

7.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.verdigris.7 — Verdigris — nature-inspired supporting color — tint step 7.

8.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.verdigris.8 — Verdigris — nature-inspired supporting color — tint step 8.

9.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.verdigris.9 — Verdigris — nature-inspired supporting color — tint step 9.

0.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.whiteGold.0 — White Gold — warm cream neutral — tint step 0.

1.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.whiteGold.1 — White Gold — warm cream neutral — tint step 1.

2.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.whiteGold.2 — White Gold — warm cream neutral — tint step 2.

3.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.whiteGold.3 — White Gold — warm cream neutral — tint step 3.

4.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.whiteGold.4 — White Gold — warm cream neutral — base color (step 4, pinned to official brand hex).

5.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.whiteGold.5 — White Gold — warm cream neutral — tint step 5.

6.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.whiteGold.6 — White Gold — warm cream neutral — tint step 6.

7.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.whiteGold.7 — White Gold — warm cream neutral — tint step 7.

8.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.whiteGold.8 — White Gold — warm cream neutral — tint step 8.

9.$description: color.brand.clearco-30.whiteGold.9 — White Gold — warm cream neutral — tint step 9.

lg.$description: contentWidth.lg — Large content width (1280px). Use for: full application layouts, dashboards, data-heavy interfaces. Maximum comfortable width for most content. Common in: main app container, dashboard layouts, admin interfaces. Beyond this, consider multi-column or sidebar layouts.

sm.$description: contentWidth.sm — Small content width (600px). Use for: prose content, documentation, blog posts, reading-focused layouts. Optimal line length for readability (~65-75 characters). Common in: article bodies, help documentation, settings panels, narrow modals.

default.$description: cursor.default — Standard cursor for non-interactive content. Use for text, containers, and static elements.

interactive.$description: cursor.interactive — Cursor for clickable/interactive elements. Use 'pointer' for buttons, links, and actionable items.

offset.$description: focus.ring.offset — Focus ring offset from element (2px). Creates gap between element and focus ring for clarity. Use for: outline-offset property. Prevents focus ring from overlapping element borders. Ensures ring is visible on both light and dark backgrounds.

width.$description: focus.ring.width — Focus ring width (3px). Thick enough to be clearly visible per WCAG 2.4.11 (Focus Appearance). Use for: outline-width property. 3px provides clear visibility without being obtrusive. Consistent across all focusable elements.

atkinsonHyperlegibleNext.$description: fontFamilies.atkinsonHyperlegibleNext — CCUI 3.0 UI heading/display sans-serif typeface optimized for accessibility. Designed by the Braille Institute for maximum legibility, especially for users with low vision. Distinct letterforms reduce character confusion (e.g., I/l/1, O/0). Use for: page titles, section headings, hero text.
atkinsonHyperlegibleNext.$value: Atkinson Hyperlegible Next, Atkinson Hyperlegible, Public Sans, Helvetica Neue, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif

body.$description: fontFamilies.body — Default body font role. References Public Sans as the system-wide default body typeface. Themes override this token to set their own body font.

ftPolar.$description: fontFamilies.ftPolar — CCUI 3.0 brand secondary/body sans-serif typeface. FT Polar is a geometric sans-serif designed for clean, modern body text. Use for: brand body copy, marketing content, secondary text. Designed by Fontsmith.
ftPolar.$value: FT Polar, Helvetica Neue, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif

fustat.$description: fontFamilies.fustat — Google Fonts alternative for FT Polar. Fustat is a geometric sans-serif with clean, modern proportions. Use as a free substitute when FT Polar is unavailable. Available on Google Fonts.
fustat.$value: Fustat, Helvetica Neue, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif

gtUltraMedian.$description: fontFamilies.gtUltraMedian — CCUI 3.0 brand primary/display serif typeface. GT Ultra Median is a high-contrast serif designed for large display sizes and editorial use. Use for: brand hero text, marketing headlines, editorial content. Part of the GT Ultra superfamily by Grilli Type.
gtUltraMedian.$value: GT Ultra Median, Georgia, Cambria, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif

heading.$description: fontFamilies.heading — Default heading font role. References Atkinson Hyperlegible Next as the system-wide default heading typeface. Themes override this token to set their own heading font.

marcellus.$description: fontFamilies.marcellus — Google Fonts alternative for GT Ultra Median. Marcellus is a flared serif inspired by classic Roman inscriptions. Use as a free substitute when GT Ultra Median is unavailable. Available on Google Fonts.
marcellus.$value: Marcellus, Georgia, Cambria, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif

mono.$description: fontFamilies.mono — Monospace font stack for code and technical content. Use for: code blocks, inline code, terminal output, data tables with alignment needs, API references. ui-monospace uses system default (SF Mono on Mac, Cascadia on Windows 11). Fallbacks cover all major platforms. All characters have equal width for alignment.
mono.$value: ui-monospace, SFMono-Regular, Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, 'Liberation Mono', 'Courier New', monospace

openSans.$description: fontFamilies.openSans — CCUI 2.1 brand body and subheading sans-serif typeface. Open Sans is a humanist sans-serif designed by Steve Matteson with excellent legibility at small sizes. Use for: body text, subheadings, and UI elements in the CCUI 2.1 theme.
openSans.$value: Open Sans, Helvetica Neue, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif

publicSans.$description: fontFamilies.publicSans — CCUI 3.0 UI body sans-serif typeface. Public Sans is a neutral, open-source typeface by USWDS optimized for UI and web readability. Use for: all body text, UI labels, form inputs, general content. LOADING: Include weights 400, 500, 600, 700 for full design system support.
publicSans.$value: Public Sans, Helvetica Neue, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif

roboto.$description: fontFamilies.roboto — Mantine default sans-serif typeface. Roboto is Google's signature typeface, a neo-grotesque sans-serif designed for screen readability. Use for: all text in Mantine-based themes.
roboto.$value: Roboto, Helvetica Neue, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif

sourceSerifPro.$description: fontFamilies.sourceSerifPro — CCUI 2.1 brand heading serif typeface. Source Serif Pro is an open-source serif designed by Frank Griesshammer for Adobe. Use for: headings and display text in the CCUI 2.1 theme. Pairs well with Open Sans.
sourceSerifPro.$value: Source Serif Pro, Georgia, Cambria, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif

2xl.$description: fontSizes.2xl — 2x large font size (22px). Use for: medium headings (h3), component titles, feature headings. Clearly heading-sized but not dominant. Common in: h3 headings, sidebar section titles, panel headers.

3xl.$description: fontSizes.3xl — 3x large font size (26px). Use for: prominent headings (h3), page section titles. Commands attention without overwhelming. Common in: h3 headings, dashboard section titles, feature section headers.

4xl.$description: fontSizes.4xl — 4x large font size (34px). Use for: major headings (h1-h2), page titles, hero text. Primary visual hierarchy anchor. Common in: page titles, h1/h2 headings, hero headlines. Pair with lineHeight.xs or lineHeight.sm for tighter leading.

lg.$description: fontSizes.lg — Large font size (18px). Use for: lead paragraphs, emphasized body text, large UI elements, h4 headings. Bridges body and heading sizes. Common in: intro paragraphs, feature descriptions, prominent labels, h4, large button text.

md.$description: fontSizes.md — Medium font size (16px). DEFAULT body text size. Use for: primary body text, paragraphs, form inputs, buttons, main content, h5 headings. Browser default - optimal for extended reading. WCAG baseline assumption for contrast calculations. Common in: body text, input values, primary UI text, h5.

sm.$description: fontSizes.sm — Small font size (14px). Use for: secondary text, table content, form labels, captions, sidebar content, h6 headings. Comfortable for extended reading in UI contexts. Common in: data tables, form labels, navigation items, secondary buttons, h6. Good balance of density and readability.

xl.$description: fontSizes.xl — Extra large font size (20px). Use for: subtitle text, section labels, prominent UI elements, blockquotes. Between body and heading scale. Common in: modal titles, section headers within content, blockquotes.

xs.$description: fontSizes.xs — Extra small font size (12px). MINIMUM readable size. Use for: helper text, timestamps, metadata, legal text, footnotes, badge content. Requires high contrast - use with strong foreground colors. Not recommended for primary content. Common in: timestamps, version numbers, copyright notices.

moz.$description: fontSmoothing.moz — Mozilla font smoothing for Firefox. Use for crisp text rendering in heading and body content. Apply to -moz-osx-font-smoothing CSS property.

webkit.$description: fontSmoothing.webkit — WebKit font smoothing for macOS/iOS. Use for crisp, thin text in heading and body text. Apply to -webkit-font-smoothing CSS property.

bold.$description: fontWeights.bold — Bold font weight (700). Use for: headings (h1-h3), strong emphasis, critical information, maximum text prominence. Reserve for true emphasis - overuse dilutes impact. Common in: h1-h3 headings, alert titles, critical labels, strong inline emphasis (<strong>).

light.$description: fontWeights.light — Light font weight (300). Use sparingly for: large display text, hero headlines, artistic/elegant contexts, stylized marketing content. CAUTION: Poor readability at small sizes or low contrast. Never use for body text or UI labels. Requires high contrast ratio. Common in: hero text, large quotes, stylized headings.

medium.$description: fontWeights.medium — Medium font weight (500). Use for: subtle emphasis, navigation items, form labels, table headers, slightly prominent UI text. Noticeable but not bold - professional emphasis. Common in: nav items, active states, form labels, table column headers, subheadings.

regular.$description: fontWeights.regular — Regular font weight (400). DEFAULT weight for all body text. Use for: paragraphs, descriptions, general content, form input values, most UI text. Optimized for extended reading. Most content should use this weight. Common in: body text, input values, descriptions, help text.

semibold.$description: fontWeights.semibold — Semibold font weight (600). Use for: buttons, important labels, card titles, moderate emphasis headings. Strong emphasis without the heaviness of bold. Common in: button text, card titles, important labels, h4-h6 headings, badge text, tab labels.

2xl.$description: gridSpacing.2xl — 2x extra large grid gap (48px). Use for: maximum separation in grids, presentation layouts, sparse artistic layouts.

lg.$description: gridSpacing.lg — Large grid gap (32px). Use for: spacious card layouts, content grids, marketing pages.

md.$description: gridSpacing.md — Medium grid gap (24px). Use for: default content grids, spacious card layouts, comfortable dashboard grids.

sm.$description: gridSpacing.sm — Small grid gap (16px). Use for: standard card grids, form layouts, compact dashboard grids.

xl.$description: gridSpacing.xl — Extra large grid gap (40px). Use for: hero grids, feature showcases, landing page layouts.

xs.$description: gridSpacing.xs — Extra small grid gap (8px). Use for: compact card grids, dense dashboard layouts, mobile-optimized grids, icon grids.

textWrap.$description: heading.textWrap — Text wrapping behavior for headings. 'wrap' allows natural line breaks, 'balance' distributes text more evenly.

normal.$description: letterSpacing.normal — Default letter spacing (0). DEFAULT for all body text and most headings. Let the typeface's natural spacing work. Optimal for reading comprehension.

tight.$description: letterSpacing.tight — Slightly tight tracking (-0.025em). Use for: large headings (h1-h2), medium display text. Subtle tightening that improves visual density without sacrificing readability.

tighter.$description: letterSpacing.tighter — Tighter tracking (-0.05em). Use for: very large display text (48px+), hero headlines, logos. Brings characters closer for visual cohesion at large sizes. CAUTION: Can reduce readability if overused.

wide.$description: letterSpacing.wide — Slightly wide tracking (0.025em). Use for: small text (12px or less), captions that need more breathing room. Improves legibility at small sizes.

wider.$description: letterSpacing.wider — Wide tracking (0.05em). Use for: small caps, labels, overlines, all-caps text. Prevents all-caps text from feeling cramped. Common in: button text (sometimes), navigation labels, category headers.

widest.$description: letterSpacing.widest — Maximum tracking (0.1em). Use for: stylistic emphasis, spaced-out headings, decorative typography. Very pronounced spacing for special typographic treatments. Use sparingly.

2xs.$description: lineHeights.2xs — Extra tight line height (130%). Use for: large headings (h1) where text needs slightly more breathing room than xs but remains compact. Matches Mantine v8 h1 lineHeight (1.3). Common in: h1 page titles, primary headings.

lg.$description: lineHeights.lg — Relaxed line height (165%). Use for: longer paragraphs, improved readability, wide content areas, users who need more visual separation. Better for sustained reading. Common in: article content, documentation, expanded descriptions, accessibility-focused interfaces.

md.$description: lineHeights.md — Normal line height (150%). WCAG MINIMUM for body text. Use for: standard body text, paragraphs, UI descriptions, form inputs, most readable content. Baseline for accessibility compliance. Common in: body paragraphs, descriptions, form values, help text, table cells.

sm.$description: lineHeights.sm — Snug line height (135%). Use for: smaller headings (h3-h6), subheadings, short multi-line text, compact interfaces. Tighter than body but readable for short passages. Common in: h3-h6 headings, card titles, navigation items, form labels, compact UI text.

xl.$description: lineHeights.xl — Loose line height (180%). Use for: long-form prose, documentation, maximum readability, accessibility accommodations. Very generous spacing between lines. Common in: blog posts, help documentation, legal text, content prioritizing readability over density.

xs.$description: lineHeights.xs — Tightest line height (120%). Use for: large display headings, hero text, single-line elements, buttons, badges. Text appears compact and impactful. CAUTION: Not accessible for multi-line body text. Only use for display text 24px+ or single-line UI elements. Common in: display headlines, hero text, button text, badge labels.

fast.$description: motion.duration.fast — Fast transitions (100ms). Use for: micro-interactions, hover states, button presses, checkbox toggles, small element transitions, focus rings. Feels instantaneous but smooth. Anything faster is imperceptible. Common in: hover color changes, button active states, toggle switches, icon transitions.

instant.$description: motion.duration.instant — Instant/no duration (0ms). Use for: prefers-reduced-motion fallback, immediate state changes, disabled animations, no-transition scenarios. CSS: transition-duration: 0ms; effectively disables transitions. ACCESSIBILITY: Use this as fallback for users who prefer reduced motion.

normal.$description: motion.duration.normal — Normal transitions (200ms). DEFAULT duration for most UI transitions. Use for: dropdown menus, tooltips, tab switches, sidebar toggles, modal fade-ins, standard UI feedback. Balanced: noticeable but not slow. Common in: Dropdown, Tooltip, Tab panels, collapsible sections.

slow.$description: motion.duration.slow — Slow transitions (300ms). Use for: larger element transitions, slide-in panels, accordion expansions, page section reveals, image transitions. Gives eye time to track larger movements. Common in: sidebar slide, accordion panels, card reveals, hero image transitions.

slower.$description: motion.duration.slower — Slower transitions (500ms). MAXIMUM recommended duration. Use for: full-page transitions, dramatic reveals, onboarding animations, marketing flourishes. Any longer feels unresponsive. Use sparingly - only for intentional dramatic effect. Common in: page transitions, hero animations, loading sequences.

ease.$description: motion.easing.ease — Standard ease curve - CSS default. Quick start, gradual slow-down. Use for: general-purpose transitions when specific easing isn't needed. Good default but 'easeOut' often feels better for UI. CSS: ease. Common in: fallback transitions, simple state changes.

easeIn.$description: motion.easing.easeIn — Ease in - starts slow, accelerates. CSS: ease-in. Use for: elements LEAVING the screen, dismissals, fade-outs, exits. Creates sense of departure/acceleration away. AVOID for entrances - feels sluggish. Common in: modal dismiss, toast exit, dropdown close, element removal animations.

easeInOut.$description: motion.easing.easeInOut — Ease in and out - slow start, fast middle, slow end. CSS: ease-in-out. Use for: elements transforming in place, position changes, size changes, bidirectional animations. Natural for movements that start and end at rest. Common in: tab transitions, carousel slides, position animations, transform effects.

easeOut.$description: motion.easing.easeOut — Ease out - starts fast, decelerates. CSS: ease-out. RECOMMENDED for most UI transitions. Use for: elements ENTERING the screen, reveals, expansions, focus states. Creates sense of arrival/settling into place. Feels responsive and natural. Common in: modal open, tooltip appear, dropdown open, hover effects.

emphasized.$description: motion.easing.emphasized — Emphasized deceleration - quick start, strong deceleration. Custom Material-inspired curve. Use for: attention-grabbing entrances, important notifications, emphasized reveals, dramatic effect. More pronounced than standard easeOut. Use sparingly for emphasis. Common in: snackbar/toast entrance, important alerts, feature reveals, celebration animations.

linear.$description: motion.easing.linear — Linear easing - constant speed, no acceleration. CSS: linear. Use for: progress bars, looping animations, continuous scrolling, mechanical movements. Feels robotic/artificial - avoid for UI interactions. Only use when constant speed is intentionally desired. Common in: progress indicators, loading spinners, continuous carousels.

emphasis.$description: motion.transition.emphasis — Emphasis transition (300ms emphasized curve). Use for: attention-grabbing entrances, important notifications, feature reveals. Pairs slow duration with the emphasized deceleration curve for dramatic yet controlled motion. Common in: toast entrance, alert appearance, onboarding reveals, celebration animations.

fast.$description: motion.transition.fast — Fast transition (100ms ease-out). Use for: micro-interactions, hover states, button presses, checkbox toggles, focus ring transitions. Pairs fast duration with ease-out for responsive, natural feel. Common in: hover color changes, toggle switches, icon transitions, focus states.

instant.$description: motion.transition.instant — Instant transition (0ms linear). Use for: prefers-reduced-motion fallback, immediate state changes, disabling animations. Pairs duration.instant with linear easing since no motion occurs. Apply as reduced-motion override for all animated elements.

normal.$description: motion.transition.normal — Normal transition (200ms ease-out). DEFAULT transition for most UI elements. Use for: dropdown menus, tooltips, tab switches, sidebar toggles, standard UI feedback. Balanced speed with natural deceleration. Common in: Dropdown open, Tooltip appear, Tab panels, collapsible sections.

slow.$description: motion.transition.slow — Slow transition (300ms ease-in-out). Use for: larger element transitions, slide-in panels, accordion expansions, section reveals. Pairs slow duration with ease-in-out for smooth bidirectional movement. Common in: sidebar slide, accordion panels, card reveals, drawer transitions.

slower.$description: motion.transition.slower — Slower transition (500ms ease-in-out). MAXIMUM recommended transition. Use for: full-page transitions, dramatic reveals, marketing flourishes. Use sparingly - only for intentional dramatic effect. Common in: page transitions, hero animations, modal entrance with backdrop.

0.$description: opacity.0 — Fully transparent (0%). Use for: hidden elements, animation start states, invisible interactive areas. Element is invisible but may still be interactive. CSS: opacity: 0; visibility: hidden for truly hidden.

5.$description: opacity.5 — 5% opacity - barely visible. Use for: extremely subtle hover states, ghost backgrounds, near-invisible separators. Only visible against high-contrast backgrounds.

10.$description: opacity.10 — 10% opacity - subtle transparency. Use for: light hover backgrounds, subtle shadows, faint overlays. Minimally perceptible change.

20.$description: opacity.20 — 20% opacity - light transparency. Use for: hover states, light overlays, muted backgrounds. Noticeable but unobtrusive.

25.$description: opacity.25 — 25% opacity - quarter visible. Use for: skeleton loading states, light dimming, subtle backgrounds. Common for placeholder content.

30.$description: opacity.30 — 30% opacity - moderate transparency. Use for: image overlays, text shadows, moderate dimming. Visible but allows content behind to show clearly.

40.$description: opacity.40 — 40% opacity - semi-transparent. Use for: medium overlays, watermarks, partially hidden content. Balanced visibility.

50.$description: opacity.50 — 50% opacity - half visible. Use for: disabled elements (semantic alias: 'disabled'), balanced overlays, de-emphasized content. CAUTION: May not meet contrast requirements for text.

60.$description: opacity.60 — 60% opacity - mostly visible. Use for: modal backdrops (semantic alias: 'overlay'), dimmed backgrounds, focus-drawing overlays. Content behind is visible but de-emphasized.

70.$description: opacity.70 — 70% opacity - high visibility. Use for: heavy overlays, strong dimming, de-emphasized backgrounds. Most content visible but clearly secondary.

75.$description: opacity.75 — 75% opacity - three-quarters visible. Use for: dark overlays, strong backgrounds, significant dimming. Mostly solid with hint of transparency.

80.$description: opacity.80 — 80% opacity - mostly solid. Use for: nearly-opaque overlays, frosted glass effects (with backdrop-filter), heavy backgrounds.

90.$description: opacity.90 — 90% opacity - nearly solid. Use for: subtle transparency effects, slight see-through, glass-like surfaces. Almost indistinguishable from solid.

100.$description: opacity.100 — Fully opaque (100%). Use for: solid elements, removing inherited transparency, default element state. CSS: opacity: 1; (default browser value).

disabled.$description: opacity.disabled — Disabled element opacity (50%). SEMANTIC alias for opacity.50. Use for: disabled buttons, inactive controls, unavailable options. Universally recognized as 'inactive'. ACCESSIBILITY: Ensure disabled elements are still perceivable and their disabled state is communicated via aria-disabled.

overlay.$description: opacity.overlay — Modal overlay opacity (60%). SEMANTIC alias for opacity.60. Use for: modal backdrops, lightbox backgrounds, focus-drawing overlays. Dims background while keeping it visible for context. Common in: Modal backdrop, Drawer overlay, image lightbox backgrounds.

none.$description: paragraphIndent.none — No paragraph indentation. Default for UI text.
paragraphSpacing.none — No paragraph spacing. Default for UI text.

default.$description: radius.default — Default border radius when no size is specified. References radius.sm (4px) as a safe default for most components. Use this when a component needs rounded corners but no specific size is mandated.

full.$description: radius.full — Full/pill radius (circular). Use for: avatar circles, round buttons, pill-shaped tags, circular indicators, FABs. Creates perfect circles on square elements or pill shapes on rectangles. Common in: Avatar, round IconButton, pill Badge, circular progress.

lg.$description: radius.lg — Large radius (16px). Use for: hero cards, featured content, marketing components, prominent UI elements. Noticeably rounded - use intentionally for emphasis or friendly tone. Common in: feature cards, promotional banners, onboarding modals.

md.$description: radius.md — Medium radius (8px). Use for: cards, modals, dialogs, larger containers, image thumbnails, panels. Creates friendly, approachable feel without being playful. Common in: Card, Modal, Popover, larger interactive surfaces.

sm.$description: radius.sm — Small radius (4px). DEFAULT for small components. Use for: buttons, inputs, dropdowns, tooltips, small cards, table cells. The workhorse radius - professional and subtle. Most form elements use this. Common in: Button, Input, Select, Badge, Alert.

xl.$description: radius.xl — Extra large radius (32px). Use for: hero sections, large promotional elements, artistic layouts, very large cards. Significantly rounded - creates soft, approachable aesthetic. Use sparingly - can feel too casual for business applications.

xs.$description: radius.xs — Extra small radius (2px). Use for: small badges, tags, inline code blocks, tiny indicators, nested elements inside sm-radius containers. Barely perceptible rounding - softens without calling attention. Common in: chip components, status dots, code snippets.

scale.$description: scale — Global scale factor for UI components. 1 = default size, 0.8 = 80% size, 1.2 = 120% size. Affects computed dimensions when frameworks support proportional scaling.

lg.$description: sizing.controlHeight.lg — Large control height (48px). Use for: prominent controls, touch-optimized UIs.

md.$description: sizing.controlHeight.md — Medium control height (42px). DEFAULT size for most controls.

sm.$description: sizing.controlHeight.sm — Small control height (36px). Use for: secondary controls, compact layouts.

xl.$description: sizing.controlHeight.xl — Extra large control height (60px). Use for: marketing forms, high-emphasis controls.

xs.$description: sizing.controlHeight.xs — Extra small control height (30px). Use for: compact forms, inline actions, space-constrained UIs.

lg.$description: sizing.icon.lg — Large icon size (24px). Use for: prominent icons, action icons, toolbar icons.

md.$description: sizing.icon.md — Medium icon size (20px). DEFAULT for most icons. Use for: standalone icons, navigation icons.

sm.$description: sizing.icon.sm — Small icon size (16px). Use for: inline icons, button icons with text, input icons.

xl.$description: sizing.icon.xl — Extra large icon size (32px). Use for: feature icons, empty state illustrations, marketing icons.

xs.$description: sizing.icon.xs — Extra small icon size (12px). Use for: inline indicators, badge icons, compact UIs.

2xl.$description: spacing.2xl — 2x extra large spacing (40px). Use for: maximum section separation, page-level padding, large hero spacing, full-width container margins.

2xs.$description: spacing.2xs — 2x extra small spacing (8px). Use for: minimal internal padding, tight icon gaps, ultra-compact components, subtle spacing between inline elements.

lg.$description: spacing.lg — Large spacing (20px). Use for: generous padding, separation between related groups, dialog/modal padding, card spacing.

md.$description: spacing.md — Medium spacing (16px). DEFAULT spacing value. Use for: standard gaps between elements, modal padding, card padding, section padding within components.

sm.$description: spacing.sm — Small spacing (12px). Use for: standard component internal padding, form field padding, list item padding, card content padding.

xl.$description: spacing.xl — Extra large spacing (32px). Use for: major section separation, page-level margins, large component padding, hero sections.

xs.$description: spacing.xs — Extra small spacing (10px). Use for: tight padding in compact components, icon-to-text gaps, inline element spacing, dense data tables.

capitalize.$description: textCase.capitalize — Capitalize first letter of each word. Use for: titles, headings.

lowercase.$description: textCase.lowercase — All lowercase. Use rarely in UI.

none.$description: textCase.none — No text transformation. Default for most text.

uppercase.$description: textCase.uppercase — All uppercase. Use for: overlines, labels, buttons (sparingly).

none.$description: textDecoration.none — No text decoration. Default for most text.

strikethrough.$description: textDecoration.strikethrough — Strikethrough text. Use for: deleted/removed content, completed tasks.

underline.$description: textDecoration.underline — Underlined text. Use for: links, emphasized content.

blockquote.$description: typography.blockquote — Blockquote text (20px light). Use for: prominent quotes, feature testimonials, highlighted citations.

lg.$description: typography.body.lg — Large body text (18px). Use for: lead paragraphs, emphasized content, feature descriptions.

md.$description: typography.body.md — Medium body text (16px). DEFAULT for paragraphs, descriptions, and primary content.

sm.$description: typography.body.sm — Small body text (14px). Use for: secondary content, captions in dense layouts, table cells, sidebar text.

xl.$description: typography.body.xl — Extra large body text (20px). Use for: intro paragraphs, prominent content, marketing copy.

button.$description: typography.button — Button text (14px semibold). Use for: all button variants, CTAs, action triggers.

caption.$description: typography.caption — Caption text (12px regular). Use for: image captions, helper text, timestamps, metadata.

code.$description: typography.code — Code text (14px regular monospace). Use for: inline code, code blocks, technical content, API references.

lg.$description: typography.display.lg — Large display text (34px light). Use for: hero headlines, marketing banners, splash screens.

md.$description: typography.display.md — Medium display text (26px light). Use for: secondary hero text, feature highlights, callouts.

h1.$description: typography.heading.h1 — Page title (34px bold). Use for: main page headings, hero titles, primary page headers.

h2.$description: typography.heading.h2 — Section heading (26px bold). Use for: major sections, content dividers, feature headers.

h3.$description: typography.heading.h3 — Subsection heading (22px semibold). Use for: subsections, panel headers, grouped content titles.

h4.$description: typography.heading.h4 — Card heading (18px semibold). Use for: card titles, modal headers, component titles.

h5.$description: typography.heading.h5 — Small heading (16px semibold). Use for: minor sections, list group titles, compact headers.

h6.$description: typography.heading.h6 — Label heading (14px semibold). Use for: label-like headings, form section titles, metadata headers.

input.$description: typography.input — Input text (16px regular). Use for: form input values, textarea content, select values.

lg.$description: typography.label.lg — Large label (16px medium). Use for: prominent labels, section labels, emphasized form fields.

md.$description: typography.label.md — Medium label (14px medium). DEFAULT for form labels, field labels, control labels.

sm.$description: typography.label.sm — Small label (12px medium). Use for: compact form labels, helper text labels, dense UI.

overline.$description: typography.overline — Overline text (12px medium, wide tracking). Use for: category labels, eyebrow text, section markers. Typically uppercase.

quote.$description: typography.quote — Quote text (18px regular italic-style). Use for: inline quotes, testimonials, pull quotes.

2xl.$description: verticalRhythm.2xl — Triple baseline (76.8px). Use for: page section breaks, major content area separations, hero-to-content transitions.

lg.$description: verticalRhythm.lg — 1.5 baselines (38.4px). Use for: heading top margins, spacing before new sections within content, emphasis breaks.

md.$description: verticalRhythm.md — Single baseline (25.6px). DEFAULT prose spacing. Use for: paragraph margins, standard content block spacing, default vertical rhythm.

sm.$description: verticalRhythm.sm — Half baseline (12.8px). Use for: heading bottom margins, spacing after inline elements, paragraph-adjacent element spacing.

xl.$description: verticalRhythm.xl — Double baseline (51.2px). Use for: major section breaks in prose, chapter-level separations, significant content divisions.

xs.$description: verticalRhythm.xs — Quarter baseline (6.4px). Use for: list item spacing within tight lists, line spacing adjustments, micro-spacing in prose.

app.$description: zIndex.app — Application layer (z-index: 100). Use for: app-level UI chrome, sidebars, persistent navigation. First elevated layer above base content. Common in: app shells, navigation drawers, persistent toolbars.

base.$description: zIndex.base — Base layer (z-index: 0). DEFAULT for all standard content. Use for: page content, cards, sections, anything in normal document flow. Establishes baseline - everything else stacks above this. Never use negative z-index unless absolutely necessary.

dropdown.$description: zIndex.dropdown — Dropdown layer (z-index: 150). Use for: dropdown menus, select options, autocomplete lists, combobox panels. Above app chrome but below sticky headers. Common in: Select menu, Dropdown, Autocomplete, Menu, Popover (when not in modal).

max.$description: zIndex.max — Maximum layer (z-index: 9999). HIGHEST layer - use sparingly. Use for: critical system overlays, loading states that must block all interaction, debug overlays. Reserved for truly exceptional cases where nothing else should appear on top.

modal.$description: zIndex.modal — Modal layer (z-index: 400). Use for: modal dialogs, side drawers, full-screen overlays, dialog content. Primary overlay content layer - above backdrop but below popovers. Common in: Modal content, Drawer content, Dialog, Sheet, full-screen menus.

overlay.$description: zIndex.overlay — Overlay layer (z-index: 300). Use for: modal backdrops, drawer overlays, lightbox backgrounds, focus-trap containers. Dims/blocks underlying content. Separate from modal content to allow proper stacking. Common in: Modal backdrop, Drawer backdrop, lightbox overlay.

popover.$description: zIndex.popover — Popover layer (z-index: 500). Use for: popovers triggered from within modals, nested floating elements, color pickers, date pickers in modals. Above modal content but below tooltips. Common in: DatePicker in modal, ColorPicker in modal, nested menus.

sticky.$description: zIndex.sticky — Sticky layer (z-index: 200). Use for: sticky headers, fixed navigation, persistent UI elements, scroll-aware banners. Stays visible during scroll but below overlay content. Common in: Sticky header, fixed sidebar, persistent action bars, scroll-to-top buttons.

tooltip.$description: zIndex.tooltip — Tooltip layer (z-index: 600). Use for: tooltips, toasts, notifications, snackbars. Near top of standard layers. Common in: Tooltip, Toast, Snackbar, notification badges, loading indicators.
